title: Microsoft‚Äôs Insane Quantum Chip
transcript: This chamber is the coldest place in the known universe. More than 40 times colder than interstellar space, but what's it actually cooling? Last week I got a call from Microsoft. I can't really share much on the phone, but we have something pretty incredible coming up that I think you'll want to see. Next thing I knew, I was on a plane to Seattle, hopping into a car, and before I knew it, inside a lab at an undisclosed location. It was here that I finally got to see what this was all about. It was here that I got to see the Myer-on-a-One. Microsoft's extreme breakthrough in quantum computing and the result of nearly 20 years of hard work. This team was able to control a subatomic particle that was only theorized until now, creating an entirely new material and a new architecture for quantum computing that's able to fit a million qubits onto this little chip. This thing would have more computation power in it than all the combined computation power in the past. Okay, but what does this actually mean? Well, a normal computer can only process things in bits, basically ones or zeros, whereas a quantum computer uses qubits that can be both in that one and zero state at the exact same time. Imagine a maze. A computer mouse has to go in each direction one at a time to find the end, but a quantum mouse can go in all directions at the same time. The more qubits you have, the more quantum mice you have that can explore these exponentially many paths at the same time, solving the maze much, much fast. To put this all in perspective, the largest quantum computer that we have right now has a little over a thousand qubits, and to expand this, it would take up football fields of space. But this new Myer-on-a-One chip will be able to house one million qubits in the palm of your hand.

He never mentions that there's a ton of problems that are in this sort of format, the mice and maze analogy works because you can think the maze as a collection of routes, but you can't make boolean logics into these type of problems, like if you ask "if(i don't eat) then(i starve)", you can't really make this into a maze and expect it to be solved quickly, that's the real downside of quantum computers.

Also superconducting Qubits, especially topological bits like majorana qubits both IBM and Microsoft are working on are really bad in the sense that it's too hard to read out, yeah it's stable and has high fidelity, but its too stable meaning you can't get information out once it's stored, think of a safe where you can't get your money out once it's stored, which defeats the purpose of a safe since you in fact loses your money.

subcomments.author: @binky6766
subcomments.comment: It's important to note that quantum computers don't actually "try" out all the paths, let alone simultaneously. (I'll try to simplify here.) Quantum computers use wavefunctions that represent all the possible paths, which exist in superposition. In order to get these wavefunctions, you have to apply quantum gates to the qubits which is sort of like coding the maze game. In order to find the solution, they then will use mechanisms like interference to increase the chances of extracting the correct path while decreasing the chances of extracting an incorrect path. It's sort of like having a bucket filled with raffle tickets, and you shake the bucket in a certain way to push the correct ticket toward the top and increase your chances of picking it.

subcomments.author: @jamesharris-usa
subcomments.comment:
You‚Äôre mostly correct, but there‚Äôs a key clarification: QPUs aren‚Äôt analog. Quantum Processing Units operate on principles of quantum mechanics, like superposition and entanglement, which allow them to process information in ways fundamentally different from classical CPUs or GPUs, not through analog signals but through discrete quantum states.
That said, you‚Äôre right that QPUs won‚Äôt directly give a ‚Äúbillion FPS‚Äù for gaming in the near future, as they‚Äôre not designed to replace GPUs for rendering tasks. However, quantum computing could potentially speed up FPS when paired with AI, particularly through techniques like interlaced predicted frames. AI frame prediction is already a reality (NVIDIA‚Äôs DLSS 3.0, which uses AI to generate intermediate frames and boost FPS). A QPU could enhance this by accelerating the AI‚Äôs inference process, for example, by optimizing neural network computations or evaluating multiple frame possibilities in parallel using quantum superposition. This could lead to faster and more accurate frame predictions, effectively increasing FPS without overburdening the GPU.
Additionally, if a game engine offloads physics calculations like ray tracing or fluid dynamics to a QPU, the rendering pipeline could become much faster. QPUs are particularly good at simulating complex systems, which could reduce the time spent on physics-heavy tasks and free up the GPU to focus on rendering, further boosting FPS. Of course, this is still speculative and depends on advancements like fault-tolerant quantum computers and new quantum algorithms tailored for real-time gaming workloads, which we‚Äôre likely years away from achieving. But the potential is there, and it‚Äôs an exciting direction to consider!

subcomments.author: @jamesharris-usa
subcomments.comment: @@alexnelson6733 The goal of quantum computing isn‚Äôt pinpoint accuracy in every step; it‚Äôs to efficiently narrow down the optimal outcome for problems intractable for classical computers. A quantum computer can represent multiple states at once, evaluating many potential solutions in parallel, where entanglement and interference help amplify the correct solutions while canceling out the wrong ones. This is evident in algorithms like Grover‚Äôs, which speeds up database searches, or Shor‚Äôs, which factors large numbers exponentially faster than classical methods. Integrating these capabilities with AI unlocks a world of processing power beyond what classical computing can achieve.

title: Quantum Computing
transcript: I need you to watch something really quickly. When a normal computer is trying to solve a problem, this is how it operates. The search agent will go through every path randomly until it ultimately reaches the destination. But you can't claim that it was the shortest or most efficient path to success until the entire space is covered. With a quantum computer, whenever the search agent encounters multiple paths, it will split and take both paths at once until it finds the fastest, most efficient path to success and all other search agents disappear. Now here are the two going up against each other. This is why you hear people saying that quantum computing will revolutionize the world because imagine AI progress in the next 10 years and you ask it to solve a problem, like how do we terraform another planet the fastest and safest way possible? It will be able to analyze every possible solution all at once and show us the fastest, most efficient and safest way to get there.

comments.author: @FaeyUmbrea
comments.comment: Except that this is completely wrong. The algorithm you showed is also not a quantum search algorithm. It's an example of a paralellized flood-fill algorithm. AI does not work in a way that can really profit from quantum computing either. AI is not looking for the best solution, it has no concept of quality of the output, it is looking for the most statistically likely solution, which mostly requires matrix multiplication math that a quantum computer would not be any faster at doing than a non-quantum one. Quantum computing is great in cases where you can phrase the mathmatical issue in a way where all incorrect answers destructively interfere with oneanother. So for your maze example, you'd need a quantum computer with enough storage to represent the entire maze, and a (currently nonexistant) algorithm that could put that maze in a superposition of containing all possible paths at once, in such a way that all dead ends and paths longer than the shortest path destructively interfere, leaving only the shortest path as a possible solution when the maze is then observed.

subcomments.author: @AngryAlfonse
subcomments.comment:
What isn't being explained is that, on a traditional computer, each branch has to be calculated sequentially. Even if it's calculating the paths "at the same time," what is actually happening is it's calculated the two paths back and forth. The compute power required increases exponentially alongside the number of paths.

With quantum computing, you could calculate the branches in a way that is actually simultaneous.

subcomments.author: @AngryAlfonse
subcomments.comment:
@@savy9017  no, it wouldn't be. To achieve the same results via parallel computing, you'd need an individual processor available for every possible branch that is simultaneously being processed. In reality, you have a finite number of processors, and end up having to calculate back and forth between branches.

In quantum, you're not dealing with binary, you have qbits, and so you can store and calculate multiple calculations at the same time on the same processor.

title: Microsoft Announces World's First Topological Quantum Chip - Majorana 1 Explained
transcript: Microsoft just announced their Myerana 1 quantum chip, the world's first topological quantum qubit array. In normal quantum computers you use qubits that can either be 0, 1, or somewhere in between the two. But your qubits are made of atoms, ions, or photons, so there's always a chance that a stray particle or random photon can bump into them, collapsing their quantum state. The research team at Microsoft's big idea was rather than hold this quantum information in a localized particle, instead to spread it across a surface or topology. They use Myerana quasi particles to hold electrons at either ends of a nanowire. This means that even if noise hits the system, the quantum state is still preserved. To make these nanowires work however required every single atom to be exactly in the right place within the material, which took the team 17 years to get right. Their nature paper just released which shows how powerful this technique is, and their architecture puts them on a pathway to realizing a million qubits that would fit on the size of a credit card. If you like science and tech breakthroughs, follow for more.

title: The Race to Harness Quantum Computing's Mind-Bending Power | The Future With Hannah Fry
transcript: HIDDEN AMONGST THESE SNOW-COVERED HILLS is a secretive institution, home to a revolutionary machine that can harness physics so strange it sounds like magic. This is IBM's research facility, it's where some of the biggest breakthroughs in the history of computer science have happened and probably going to be home to a few more because this is where they build quantum computers. Their potential is huge, promising breakthroughs in material science, medicine, fundamental physics and more. But there is a dark side because they will come with the ability to decrypt all internet communication. Some say there is now a quantum arms race between the United States and its biggest economic rival, China. I'm Professor Hannah Fry, mathematician and writer. I want to know where quantum technology will take us and with international security under the threat, who will come out on top? This is the research headquarters for one of the oldest companies in tech, IBM. They've been inventing new computing technology here since the 1960s. It's like the Jetsons meets the Flintstones. Quantum scientist Olivia Lanez is showing me IBM's newest experimental machine. This big shiny behemoth is IBM Quantum System 2. Sounds like it's on. What is the big deal though? I mean, why not just build an ordinary supercomputer? It's a totally different avenue. It's not just supercomputers but better or AI but more powerful. It's an entirely different way of computing. The big difference is the computer's ability to harness the mysterious effects of quantum physics. Standard computers, they calculate by using billions of tiny little on and off switches known as bits. Now these things, they're very reliable. They work together in sequence. So if you ask a standard computer to solve a maze, it will do so by checking through every possible path one by one until it finds a solution. Depending on the size of the maze, that could take seconds or minutes or potentially for a really big maze even years. A quantum computer on the other hand works a little bit differently. There, the bits are known as quantum bits or qubits and rather than just being on or off, a qubit can be held in something called a superposition where it can be both on and off at the same time. Now, okay, I know that that doesn't really make a lot of sense but unfortunately that is just how physics works down at the atomic level. So go with me. This bizarre ability of a qubit to be in two states at once means that a series of qubits can solve lots of calculations simultaneously. And so if you ask a quantum computer to solve a maze, it means it can consider all possible routes at once, giving you the answer in an instant. It could allow a quantum computer to complete in minutes, computation so complex that it would take today's supercomputers millions of years. But that's not the only reason they're a game changer for science. I think what it really comes down to is that nature is quantum mechanical. When you get down to molecular and atomic interactions, nature does not obey classical physics. It's a very crude approximation. And if we really want to understand how nature evolves in time, we have to have a system that obeys quantum physics. So I guess this finally gives us the opportunity to do simulations down at the level of atoms. And when you have that, I mean, you can design drugs at the level of atoms. That's right. You can design materials, batteries. And we haven't had this before. We've never had that. I think when quantum computing comes up in conversation, people are excited about it but they're excited about the amount of power it gives you about how quickly you can do computations. Because, OK, sure, all of that stuff might be true. But we should be thinking of this as though someone has just invented the telescope. comments.author: @ONRIPRESENCE
comments.comment:
Fun fact: quantum computing hardware contains a lot of analog components, especially the physical qubits themselves. The programmed signals we use to excite a quantum device should more or less match its resonating frequency and thus typically take the form of continuous, modulated sine waves. (In other words, square waves are not suitable to excite a physical qubit, however a compatible digital-to-analog converter may be employed to generate the required resonating waveform).

The manipulation of waves in the quantum confined devices, under the right conditions, is what allows one to obtain the interference, entanglement, and superposition for the quantum experiments :)

- a quantum hardware engineer who builds quantum computers for a living
